   13    S  10.  Subparagraph  (i) of paragraph (f) of subdivision 2 of section
   14  421-a of the real property tax law, as amended by  chapter  253  of  the

   16    (i) with respect to units subject to the provisions of this section on
   17  the effective date of this subparagraph such a unit becomes vacant after
   18  the  expiration  of  such  ten  year  period  or  applicable law or act;
   19  provided, however, [that such units may be decontrolled pursuant to  the
   20  rent  regulation  reform act of 1993 and provided further that] the rent
   21  shall not be decontrolled for a unit which the commissioner  of  housing
   22  and  community renewal or a court of competent jurisdiction finds became
   23  vacant because the landlord or any person acting on his  behalf  engaged

   31  tenant  who  vacated  such  unit until restoration of possession of such
   32  tenant, if the tenant so desires, in which case the rent of such  tenant

   34  compliance with such other remedy, including, but not  limited  to,  all
   35  remedies provided for by the emergency tenant protection act of nineteen

   37  the commissioner of housing and community renewal, as  shall  be  deter-

   39  priate; provided, however, that if a tenant fails  to  accept  any  such
   40  offer  of  restoration  of  possession,  such  unit shall return to rent
   41  stabilization at the previously regulated rent; or
   42    S 11. This act shall take effect immediately.

BILL NUMBER:S1793

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the tax law and the real property tax law, in relation to
eliminating rent regulation protection for certain high income tenants
and high rent housing accommodations; and to repeal certain provisions
of the emergency housing rent control law, the administrative code of
the city of New York, the emergency tenant protection act of nineteen
seventy-four and the tax law relating thereto

PURPOSE:
To end high-rent vacancy decontrol of rent stabilized
apartments.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1 repeals paragraphs (m) and (n) of
subdivision 2 of §2 of chapter 274 of the laws of 1946.

§ 2 repeals §2-a of chapter 274 of the laws of 1946

§3 repeals subparagraphs (j) and (k) of paragraph 2 of subdivision e
of §26-403 of the administrative code of the city of New York

§4 repeals §26-403.1 of the administrative code of the city of New York

§5 repeals §26-504.1 and §26-504.2 of the administrative code of the
city of New York

§6 repeals §26-504.3 of the administrative code of city of New York

§7 repeals paragraphs 12 and 13 of subdivision a of§5 and §4 of
chapter 576 of the laws of 1974

§8 repeals §5-a and §4 of chapter 576 of the laws of 1974

§9 repeals subdivision 3 of § 171-b of the tax law and amends
subdivision 7 of such section as amended by chapter 170 of the
laws of 1994

§10 amends subparagraph (i) of paragraph (f) of subdivision 2 of
§421-a of the real property law, as amended by chapter 253 of the
laws of 1993

JUSTIFICATION:
The rent stabilization program is necessary to provide
affordable housing for New Yorkers. High rent vacancy decontrol has
led to the decontrol of large numbers of
apartments. Ending this damaging practice is necessary to ensure
affordable housing and stabilization of neighborhoods.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
New bill has been previously introduced.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.


EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
